Key Arguments: The bill threatens freedom and the advancement of knowledge.
The Australian public can discern information without government interference.
ACMA does not have a monopoly on truth and cannot determine what is correct.
Truth is subjective and varies across cultures and time.
ACMA lacks the resources to monitor and determine correct information.
The bill threatens democratic freedom of speech.
The government could use the bill to push political agendas.
The bill could stifle scientific, economic, and social progress by preventing the dissemination of new ideas.
The bill does not adequately define key terms like 'misinformation' and 'disinformation'.
The bill unfairly requires platforms to police content.
The penalties imposed by the bill are harsh and undeserved.
Notable Quotes: This bill is a threat to the freedom of the Australian public and the advancement of knowledge in this country.
The ACMA does not have a monopoly on truth.
Truth is different things to different people and different cultures at different times in history.
The government's censorship of information on the basis that it is 'misinformation' threatens our democratic right to freedom of speech.
